Perfect. Act 2
Assistant
Now that we have the Act 1 character sheets set, let’s move forward with Act 2. These will include updated information for each character, including secret knowledge, objectives that align with the investigation of the murder, and relationships that reflect the shifting dynamics as the mystery unfolds. The details will mirror the structure from Jazz Age Jeopardy (JAJ), keeping the essential characters more detailed and non-essential characters adjusted accordingly.

Essential Characters (Full Detail) - Act 2

1. Sable Blackthorn (The Ambitious Witch)

Role: The Murderer (Unknown to Others) New Knowledge: You succeeded in your plan to kill Serafina using a forbidden spell. You’ve been practicing dark magic in secret, and tonight, you finally put it to use. Now, you must do everything in your power to avoid suspicion and deflect attention onto someone else. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Avoid suspicion by acting genuinely shocked and devastated by Serafina’s death. You’ve prepared for this, so you need to play the part convincingly.
  • Deflect blame onto someone else. You’ve been quietly observing the coven’s power struggles, and now is your chance to manipulate others into suspecting someone else of the murder. Lilith, Rowena, or Balthazar could be good scapegoats.
  • Keep your dark magic hidden. If anyone finds out that you’ve been dabbling in forbidden spells, your entire plan could fall apart. You must destroy any evidence that might link you to the murder.
  • Gather allies who can help support your rise to power. Even though Serafina is gone, you still need to solidify your position before anyone else makes a move for leadership.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Lilith Ravenspell: Lilith is a prime target for suspicion. She’s always been vocal about wanting Serafina’s position, and it wouldn’t take much to convince the others that she’s responsible for the murder. Be careful, though—she’s just as clever as you are.
  • Balthazar Thorn: Balthazar’s connection to dark magic makes him a potential suspect. If the others start to suspect that dark magic was involved in the murder, you could subtly suggest that Balthazar had the motive and means.
  • Fiona Moonshadow: Fiona’s grief over Serafina’s death could make her an easy pawn in your game. Use her emotional state to manipulate her into supporting your version of events.

2. Serafina Eldridge (The High Witch – Murder Victim)

Role: The Ghost New Knowledge: You’ve been killed, but your spirit remains in the world of the living. Though you cannot directly reveal the truth about your murder, you can influence events by communicating with certain witches, especially Rowena, the necromancer. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Communicate with Rowena to try to guide the investigation toward the truth. You cannot explicitly say who killed you, but you can give cryptic clues to those who can hear you.
  • Observe the investigation and gather information. Though you are no longer alive, you still have a role to play. You know the truth, but you must be careful not to make your presence too obvious.
  • Confront Sable subtly through your ghostly presence. You can’t accuse her directly, but your presence should unsettle her and make her more nervous. If she slips up, it could lead to her downfall.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Rowena Nightshade: Rowena is your main link to the living world. You need her to communicate your cryptic warnings and help guide the others toward the truth.
  • Sable Blackthorn: You now know that Sable is your murderer. You cannot reveal this directly, but your ghostly presence can be used to haunt her and make her feel the weight of her crime.
  • Lilith Ravenspell: You always saw Lilith as a rival, and though she didn’t kill you, she’s a strong candidate for leadership. Watch her closely to see how she reacts to your death.

3. Lilith Ravenspell (The Rival Witch)

New Knowledge: You knew that Serafina’s leadership was weakening, but you never expected her to be murdered. Now that she’s dead, the power vacuum is real, and you need to act quickly if you want to claim your rightful place as the coven’s new leader. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Seize the opportunity created by Serafina’s death to assert your claim to leadership. You’ve been preparing for this moment for years, and now is the time to act.
  • Deflect suspicion. Though you didn’t kill Serafina, others may suspect you due to your long-standing rivalry with her. You need to prove your innocence by helping to find the real murderer.
  • Form alliances with those who might support your claim to leadership. You’ll need strong allies to counter any opposition from witches like Sable or Balthazar.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Sable Blackthorn: You’ve always seen Sable as a potential rival for leadership, but now you’re starting to suspect that she may be hiding something. Keep an eye on her, but don’t let her know that you’re suspicious.
  • Balthazar Thorn: Balthazar’s neutrality makes him a potential ally, but his dark magic also makes him a suspect. Be careful about where you place your trust.
  • Fiona Moonshadow: Fiona’s grief over Serafina’s death could make her a valuable ally, or she could become a liability. Use her emotions to your advantage if necessary.

4. Balthazar Thorn (The Warlock with Forbidden Knowledge)

New Knowledge: You had no part in Serafina’s murder, but you immediately recognize the use of dark magic in her death. Though you’ve dabbled in forbidden spells yourself, you know that this particular spell is beyond even your abilities. Someone in the coven has been practicing far darker magic than you anticipated. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Uncover the truth behind Serafina’s death. You’re intrigued by the power used to kill her, and you want to find out who’s responsible. This could be an opportunity to gain more knowledge—if you play your cards right.
  • Clear your name. Your connection to dark magic makes you an easy suspect, but you need to prove that you had nothing to do with the murder.
  • Manipulate the investigation to suit your interests. You don’t need to be the leader, but you do need to stay in control of the situation. Use your influence to steer the investigation in a way that benefits you.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Sable Blackthorn: Sable is ambitious, but now you’re starting to wonder if she’s more dangerous than you realized. Keep her close, but don’t reveal too much.
  • Rowena Nightshade: Rowena’s connection to the dead could be useful in uncovering the truth. Work with her to gather information from the spirit world.
  • Lilith Ravenspell: Lilith is a potential ally, but you don’t fully trust her. Watch her carefully to see how she reacts to the investigation.

5. Rowena Nightshade (The Necromancer)

New Knowledge: Serafina’s death has shaken the coven, but you can still communicate with her spirit. As the necromancer, you have the unique ability to contact the dead, and Serafina’s ghost has been reaching out to you with cryptic warnings. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Communicate with Serafina’s spirit to gather information about her murder. She can’t tell you outright who killed her, but she can give you clues that may help guide the investigation.
  • Use your necromantic abilities to influence the investigation. You have a direct connection to the spirit world, and others may rely on you for guidance. Be careful, though—some may fear your power.
  • Stay neutral in the leadership struggle for now. You have no interest in leading the coven, but you do need to protect yourself from those who might see you as a threat.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Serafina Eldridge: Serafina’s ghost is your main source of information about the murder. You need to listen carefully to her warnings and communicate them to the others without revealing too much too soon.
  • Sable Blackthorn: You’ve always been wary of Sable’s ambition, and now you’re starting to suspect that she may be involved in Serafina’s death. Keep an eye on her, but don’t confront her directly.
  • Balthazar Thorn: Balthazar’s knowledge of dark magic makes him a potential suspect, but you also recognize that he could be a valuable ally in the investigation.

6. Fiona Moonshadow (The Healer Witch)

New Knowledge: Serafina’s death has devastated you. You loved her deeply, and now you want nothing more than to find out who is responsible for her murder. You suspect that one of the more ambitious witches in the coven may be to blame, but you’re too emotional to think clearly. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Find out who killed Serafina. You’re driven by grief and a desire for justice, but you need to be careful not
Assistant
to let your emotions cloud your judgment.
    - Stay loyal to Serafina’s memory. Even in death, you believe that Serafina was the rightful leader of the coven, and you’ll do whatever it takes to defend her legacy.
  • Watch for signs of deception. You’re starting to realize that some of the witches you trusted may not be who they seem. Be careful about who you rely on.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Sable Blackthorn: You’ve always been wary of Sable’s ambition, and now you’re starting to suspect that she may be involved in Serafina’s death. Keep an eye on her, but don’t act too quickly.
  • Lilith Ravenspell: Lilith is another potential suspect, though you’re not sure if she’s capable of murder. Keep her at arm’s length for now.
  • Rowena Nightshade: You’ve turned to Rowena for guidance in communicating with Serafina’s spirit. Trust her advice, but be careful not to let your emotions get the best of you.

Non-Essential Characters (75% Detail) - Act 2

7. Gideon Blackthorn (Sable’s Cousin)

New Knowledge: You’ve been keeping a close eye on Sable, and now you’re starting to notice some troubling behavior. You don’t know if she’s involved in Serafina’s murder, but you’re beginning to suspect that she’s hiding something from you. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Protect Sable, but don’t let her know that you’re suspicious. You need to find out what she’s hiding without confronting her directly.
  • Gather information from the other witches. You’re not directly involved in the investigation, but you can still keep an ear out for any clues that might point to the real murderer.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Sable Blackthorn: Your cousin and closest ally. You’ve always supported her, but now you’re starting to worry that she’s hiding something from you.
  • Fiona Moonshadow: You sympathize with Fiona’s grief, and you’ve been trying to comfort her in the wake of Serafina’s death.
  • Balthazar Thorn: Balthazar’s dark magic makes you uneasy, but you’re not sure if he’s involved in the murder.
I'll continue working on the remaining Act 2 character sheets for both essential and non-essential characters in the next message! Let me know if this works so far.
User
Continune
Assistant
Here's the continuation of Act 2 character sheets for the remaining essential and non-essential characters.

Non-Essential Characters (75% Detail) - Act 2

8. Thalia Shadowfrost (Potion Master’s Apprentice)

New Knowledge: You’ve noticed that some of the ingredients for dark potions have gone missing from Isolde’s stores. You haven’t told anyone yet, but you’re starting to suspect that someone in the coven is using dark magic. You’re not sure if it’s related to Serafina’s murder, but you can’t shake the feeling that something is terribly wrong. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Investigate the missing ingredients. You’re not directly involved in the investigation, but you can quietly gather information about who might have taken the forbidden herbs.
  • Be careful who you trust. You’re still relatively new to the coven’s politics, and you don’t want to accuse the wrong person. Stay quiet and observe the behavior of those around you.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Isolde Winters: Your mentor. You haven’t told her about the missing ingredients yet, but you’re worried that someone has been stealing from her.
  • Sable Blackthorn: You’ve always admired Sable’s power, but now you’re starting to wonder if she’s involved in something dangerous.
  • Rowena Nightshade: You’ve considered talking to Rowena about your suspicions, but you’re not sure if you can trust her.

9. Isolde Winters (Potion Master)

New Knowledge: You’ve recently discovered that some of your more dangerous potion ingredients have gone missing. Though you don’t have enough evidence to confront anyone, you’re beginning to suspect that someone has been experimenting with forbidden potions. You didn’t expect Serafina to be murdered, but now you’re wondering if the missing ingredients are related to her death. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Investigate the missing ingredients and see if they’re connected to Serafina’s murder. You need to find out who’s been tampering with your supplies before more damage is done.
  • Stay neutral in the investigation, but offer your potion-making skills to help those who are trying to find the murderer.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Thalia Shadowfrost: Your apprentice. You’ve noticed that she’s been acting a little nervous lately, but you’re not sure if it’s related to the missing ingredients.
  • Sable Blackthorn: Sable has always been ambitious, but now you’re starting to suspect that she’s been using dark potions. Be careful around her.
  • Lilith Ravenspell: You’ve always respected Lilith’s power, but you don’t fully trust her. Keep an eye on her during the investigation.

10. Ravenna Silverleaf (The Enchantress)

New Knowledge: You’ve noticed that some of the protective wards around the coven have been weakening over the past few weeks. You haven’t told anyone yet, but you’re starting to wonder if someone has been tampering with them. Serafina’s murder was a shock to you, but you’re beginning to think that it may be related to the weakened wards. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Investigate the weakened wards and see if they were tampered with. You need to find out if someone in the coven has been undermining its defenses.
  • Help with the investigation by using your enchantment skills to gather information or protect those who might be in danger.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Serafina Eldridge: You always admired Serafina’s leadership, but now you’re starting to wonder if she knew about the weakened wards.
  • Sable Blackthorn: You’ve noticed that Sable has been acting strangely lately, and you’re starting to suspect that she may be involved in the weakening of the wards.
  • Rowena Nightshade: You’ve considered consulting Rowena about the spirits’ involvement, but you’re wary of her necromantic powers.

    - Stay quiet about your suspicions for now. You’re still new to the coven and don’t want to cause trouble by accusing the wrong person.
  • Observe the behavior of those around you and see if anyone seems nervous or guilty.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Galen Thornridge: Your mentor. You’ve considered telling him about the missing herbs, but you’re worried about getting someone in trouble without proof.
  • Sable Blackthorn: You’ve always admired Sable, but now you’re starting to wonder if she’s been involved in something dangerous.

You’re now certain that someone in the coven has been practicing forbidden magic, but you don’t know who. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Share your vision with the others, but be careful not to accuse anyone directly. Your vision was unclear, and you don’t want to point fingers without proof.
  • Continue observing the investigation and see if any of the clues match your vision.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Rowena Nightshade: You’ve consulted Rowena about your visions in the past, and you’re considering talking to her again about what you’ve seen.
  • Sable Blackthorn: Sable’s ambition makes her a likely suspect in your mind, but you don’t have any concrete evidence against her yet.

22. Astra Darkflame (The Pyromancer)

New Knowledge: You've noticed a strange fluctuation in your fire magic lately—your flames feel weaker than they should. You’re beginning to suspect that someone is dampening your powers, and it might have something to do with Serafina's murder. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Investigate the weakening of your fire magic and see if it’s connected to the murder. Someone could be tampering with your powers to cover their tracks.
  • Stay alert and use your fire magic to defend yourself if needed.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Lilith Ravenspell: You’ve always been cautious around Lilith, but now you’re starting to suspect that she might be responsible for your weakening magic.
  • Sable Blackthorn: You admire Sable’s ambition, but you’re now suspicious of her true intentions.

23. Orion Windwalker (The Wind Mage)

New Knowledge: Recently, you've noticed strange gusts of wind in areas where you weren’t controlling the air. You're starting to believe that someone else is manipulating the wind, and you suspect it could be related to Serafina’s death. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Investigate the strange winds and see if they’re connected to the murder. You need to determine if someone is using elemental magic to cover their tracks.
  • Stay neutral in the investigation, but be ready to defend yourself with your wind magic if necessary.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Sable Blackthorn: You’ve noticed Sable’s growing ambition and are starting to feel uneasy about her intentions.
  • Balthazar Thorn: Balthazar’s knowledge of dark magic makes him a potential suspect in your mind.

24. Calista Ravenshade (The Diviner)

New Knowledge: You've had a troubling vision since Serafina’s death. You saw shadows surrounding the coven, but the meaning of the vision is unclear. You believe that someone is hiding a dangerous secret, but you can’t yet pinpoint who it is. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Continue interpreting your vision. The shadows are closing in, and you need to figure out what they mean before it’s too late.
  • Help the investigation by using your divination skills, but avoid accusing anyone until you’re sure of your vision’s meaning.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Sable Blackthorn: Sable’s ambitions make her a likely candidate for the shadows you saw in your vision, but you need more evidence before you confront her.
  • Fiona Moonshadow: Fiona has been deeply affected by Serafina’s death, and you’ve been trying to help her make sense of her grief.

25. Galen Thornridge (The Herbalist)

New Knowledge: You’ve noticed that several rare herbs used in dangerous spells have gone missing from your stores. You don’t know who took them, but you’re starting to suspect that someone in the coven is using them for dark magic. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Investigate the missing herbs. You need to find out if they were used in Serafina’s murder or if they’re part of something even darker.
  • Stay neutral in the investigation, but offer your herbalist knowledge to help those trying to uncover the truth.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Rowena Nightshade: You’ve worked with Rowena before, but you’re starting to wonder if her connection to the dead might involve forbidden magic.
  • Sable Blackthorn: You’re starting to suspect that Sable might be the one who stole your herbs, but you don’t have enough evidence yet.

26. Vesper Darkmoon (The Shadow Witch)

New Knowledge: You’ve been sensing strange disturbances in the shadows lately, almost as if someone else is trying to manipulate them. You don’t know who it is, but you’re starting to suspect that dark magic is at play, possibly connected to Serafina’s murder. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Investigate the disturbances in the shadows and see if they’re linked to the murder. You need to figure out who’s been tampering with your domain.
  • Use your shadow magic to stay hidden and gather information from the shadows without revealing yourself.
Relationships (Act 2):
    - Sable Blackthorn: You’ve noticed Sable’s growing power and are starting to feel uneasy about her control over the coven’s politics.
  • Balthazar Thorn: Balthazar’s connection to dark magic makes him a likely suspect in your mind.

27. Mira Shadowspire (The Elemental Witch)

New Knowledge: You’ve recently felt a strange shift in the balance of the elements, as though someone else is manipulating them in ways that shouldn’t be possible. You suspect that dark magic is involved, possibly connected to Serafina’s death. Objectives for Act 2:
    - Investigate the elemental disturbances and see if they’re linked to the murder. You need to determine if someone is using elemental magic to hide their involvement.
  • Offer your elemental magic skills to help protect others, but don’t reveal too much about your suspicions.

    - Sable Blackthorn: You’ve noticed that Sable has been acting strangely, and you’re starting to suspect that she’s involved in the elemental disturbances.
  • Rowena Nightshade: You’ve considered asking Rowena for help, but you’re wary of her necromantic powers.

Final Notes for Act 2:

In this phase, each character is grappling with the fallout of Serafina’s murder and uncovering clues that may point to the murderer (Sable Blackthorn). The characters are more suspicious of one another, with new knowledge surfacing and allegiances shifting. The essential characters play key roles in driving the investigation, while non-essential characters contribute by observing and gathering clues related to their own fields of expertise. This completes the Act 2 character sheets for all 27 characters! Let me know if you need any final tweaks.

Assistant
You're correct in pointing out that there was a discrepancy between the initial nine essential characters and the six detailed essential characters later on. Let me clarify the situation.

Originally Listed Nine Essential Characters:

In the earlier phase, I listed the following nine characters as essential for the murder to be solved:
    1. Serafina Eldridge (The Victim)
  1. Sable Blackthorn (The Murderer)
  2. Lilith Ravenspell (Rival Witch)
  3. Fiona Moonshadow (The Healer Witch)
  4. Rowena Nightshade (Necromancer)
  5. Balthazar Thorn (Warlock)
  6. Gideon Blackthorn (Sable’s Cousin)
  7. Thalia Shadowfrost (Potion Master’s Apprentice)
  8. Isolde Winters (Potion Master)
However, in later responses, I focused primarily on six characters for full detail (the ones most critical to the murder and investigation).

Should We Include the Other Three?

The remaining three characters from the original list—Gideon Blackthorn, Thalia Shadowfrost, and Isolde Winters—were initially considered important but are slightly less central to the immediate investigation compared to the core six. That said, these characters still play valuable roles and add depth to the game:
    - Gideon Blackthorn: Closely related to the murderer and aware that something is off with Sable.
  • Thalia Shadowfrost: Notices missing ingredients, which could point toward the use of dark magic.
  • Isolde Winters: Aware that potion ingredients have been tampered with, providing key clues.

Conclusion:

If you're aiming for a robust investigation and need to ensure that all critical roles are filled, I recommend including all nine characters as essential. This will give the game a richer experience and ensure that there’s enough depth to the investigation. If you are fine with focusing only on the six most central roles, then you can prioritize those. Either way, those three additional characters (Gideon, Thalia, and Isolde) would still be important to the overall flow of the mystery and help enhance the plot.

Assistant
Here are the updates you requested for your Coven Murder Mystery Event, including the murder mystery overview, clue sheets, and event outline/timeline. All are now aligned with the enhanced character details.

Murder Mystery Overview

Title: The Hexed Circle: Coven Murder Mystery

Introduction: Welcome to “The Hexed Circle,” a fully immersive murder mystery experience set in the mystical world of witches and dark magic. Guests will take on the roles of members of a secretive coven and magical beings to uncover the truth behind the murder of the powerful High Witch, Serafina Eldridge. This game is structured into two acts, with interactions, investigations, and a scavenger hunt for clues woven throughout.
Essential Characters (9):
    1. Serafina Eldridge (The Victim)
  1. Sable Blackthorn (The Murderer)
  2. Lilith Ravenspell (Rival Witch)
  3. Fiona Moonshadow (Healer Witch)
  4. Rowena Nightshade (Necromancer)
  5. Balthazar Thorn (Warlock)
  6. Gideon Blackthorn (Sable’s Cousin)
  7. Thalia Shadowfrost (Potion Apprentice)
  8. Isolde Winters (Potion Master)
Non-Essential Characters (18): Remaining characters provide context, intrigue, and extra dynamics but are not required to solve the murder.

Event Outline/Timeline

1. Guest Arrival & Cocktail Hour (First 15 minutes)

    - Guests arrive, are introduced to their roles, and begin mingling.
  • Light Hors d’oeuvres and themed cocktails are served.
  • Characters begin subtle in-character interactions, building alliances or rivalries.

2. Official Welcome & Game Start (After the last guest arrives)

    - After the first 15 minutes, the host officially welcomes everyone, introduces the mystery, and goes over the rules.
  • Guests are reminded to stay in character and that they are part of a sacred coven gathering.

3. Act 1: The Gathering and Murder (15-30 minutes)

    - The setting is a coven ritual under a full moon, led by High Witch Serafina Eldridge.
  • Just before the ritual is completed, Serafina is found dead.
  • Game Master Announcement: The GM announces Serafina’s murder, and players begin their initial investigation, starting with their immediate reactions and suspicions.

4. Dinner Break (30 minutes)

    - Guests break from the game to enjoy their first and second courses.
  • Although they can discuss the game thus far, no critical information or secrets should be revealed.

5. Scavenger Hunt for Clues (20-30 minutes)

    - Hidden clues (physical and/or written) are scattered throughout the room or venue. Each clue ties into different characters' magical specialties and their connection to the murder.
  • Clues should be gathered and interpreted as a group or individually.

6. Act 2: The Investigation (30-45 minutes)

    - Guests interrogate one another based on the clues they’ve found.
  • Key Interrogation Questions are provided for guidance, focusing on accusations and the gathering of more evidence.
  • Players continue acting in-character while attempting to solve the murder.

7. The Final Vote & Conclusion (15 minutes)

    - Players cast their final vote on who they believe the murderer is.
  • The GM reveals the murderer and wraps up the story.

8. Awards & Conclusion (10 minutes)

    - Guests receive awards such as Keen Detective, Best Actor/Actress, Falsely Accused, and Cold-Blooded Killer (if the murderer was identified).

Clue Sheets & Scavenger Hunt Items

Clue Categories:

    1. Magical Objects & Ingredients:
    - A Blood-Stained Ritual Dagger: This ceremonial dagger is found near Serafina’s body. Could it be the murder weapon?
  • Burnt Spell Scroll: Found near the site of the ritual, the scroll contains a partially destroyed forbidden spell. Who would dare to use it?
  • Missing Herbs from Isolde’s Supplies: Rare herbs have been stolen. Who has been dabbling in dark potions?
  1. Personal Items:
    - A Torn Robe Fragment: This fabric belongs to one of the coven members. Who got close enough to tear their robe near the murder?
  • A Secret Letter: A cryptic note written by Serafina, warning of an impending betrayal. Who did she suspect?
  1. Scavenger Hunt Clues:
    - A Hidden Crystal Orb (Broken): Serafina’s divination tool, shattered during the ritual. Was it destroyed in a magical struggle?
  • Book of Forbidden Spells: A dark book filled with dangerous incantations. Who was studying it?

Red Herrings:

    - A Banishment Herb: Often used to repel spirits, but its presence is unrelated to the murder.
  • A Shadowy Cloak: Left behind during the ritual, but not involved in Serafina’s death.
These updates now reflect the deeper character interactions and enhanced game flow. Please review, and let me know if anything needs further refinement or adjustment!

Assistant
Here's the updated Host Guide and Event Overview, with the same level of depth and character count as the Jazz Age Jeopardy example:

Host Guide for The Hexed Circle: Coven Murder Mystery Dinner

Event Overview

Welcome to The Hexed Circle, a fully immersive murder mystery experience in which guests will take on the roles of witches and magical beings attending a sacred coven ritual. The murder of the High Witch, Serafina Eldridge, will disrupt the night, and it’s up to the participants to investigate the cause of her death, discover the murderer, and bring them to justice. The event will take place in three phases:
    1. Act 1: The Gathering and Murder
  1. Dinner Break
  2. Act 2: The Investigation, Scavenger Hunt, and Final Vote
This guide will provide you, the Host, with instructions for running the event, including scripted announcements, prompts to keep the guests engaged, and guidance on facilitating the investigation.

Host Responsibilities

    - Ensure guests stay in character throughout the evening. Prompt them with their objectives and relationships as needed.
  • Introduce each phase of the event at the appropriate time, following the timeline provided.
  • Keep the flow of the evening moving by announcing transitions between phases.
  • Provide hints or guidance if the investigation stalls, but be careful not to reveal key information prematurely.
  • Maintain the suspense and encourage guests to fully engage in their roles.

Pre-Event Setup

    1. Guest Role Assignment: Ensure all guests have received their character sheets prior to the event, so they arrive in costume and ready to play their roles. Key characters to ensure are filled include:
    - Serafina Eldridge (The Victim)
  • Sable Blackthorn (The Murderer)
  • Lilith Ravenspell (Rival Witch)
  • Fiona Moonshadow (The Healer Witch)
  • Rowena Nightshade (The Necromancer)
  • Balthazar Thorn (The Warlock)
  • Gideon Blackthorn (Sable’s Cousin)
  • Thalia Shadowfrost (Potion Master’s Apprentice)
  • Isolde Winters (Potion Master)
  1. Set the Scene: Decorate the space to resemble a mystical coven gathering. Candles, mystical symbols, and dark, witchy décor will enhance the atmosphere. Arrange the room to allow for easy movement during the scavenger hunt.
  2. Clue Preparation: Ensure that all physical clues (e.g., the blood-stained dagger, the torn robe fragment) are hidden in their designated locations. These clues will be discovered during the scavenger hunt and should be placed strategically around the room.
  3. Timing the Event: The event will last about 2 to 2.5 hours. Ensure smooth transitions between phases and keep the investigation moving at a good pace. The timeline below outlines when each phase will take place.

Event Timeline and Key Host Prompts

1. Guest Arrival and Cocktail Hour (First 15 minutes)

    - Guests arrive, receive a welcome drink, and are encouraged to mingle in character.
  • Host Prompt: “Welcome, witches and magical beings, to our sacred coven gathering under the full moon. Tonight, our ritual will strengthen our bonds and protect us from the growing darkness outside. But remember, not all magic is pure, and some harbor hidden motives.”
  • During this time: Encourage guests to interact with one another. Key characters should be developing alliances or rivalries subtly during this period. Remind the guests that they are part of a powerful coven gathering.

2. Official Welcome and Game Start (After 15 minutes)

    - Once the last guest arrives, the host officially welcomes everyone and introduces the murder mystery rules.
  • Host Prompt: “Witches and warlocks, now that we are all gathered, let us begin our sacred ritual. You are all bound by ancient magic, and tonight, we shall strengthen those bonds. However, not all is as it seems, and soon, a darkness will fall upon us.”
  • Announce the rules: Remind everyone to stay in character and follow their character sheets closely. Explain that they must investigate and discover the murderer through clues and interrogation.

3. Act 1: The Gathering and the Murder (15-30 minutes)

    - Guests participate in the coven’s ritual, led by Serafina Eldridge.
  • Host Script (to read during the ritual): “Under the light of the full moon, we join our power as one. But beware, for even the moon has a shadow, and betrayal lurks within our circle.”
  • Murder Announcement: After a few moments of mystical chanting (allow the guests to mingle and interact briefly), the host announces Serafina’s death.
  • Host Script: “Witches! Something is wrong! Serafina Eldridge has fallen! Dark magic is at play. Someone among us has betrayed the coven and committed the ultimate crime.”
  • During this time: The guests should react in-character to the murder, expressing shock and suspicion. Key characters such as Lilith, Rowena, and Balthazar should immediately begin casting doubts on others.

4. Dinner Break (30 minutes)

    - Guests break for the first and second courses of the dinner. During this time, they are encouraged to relax, but no critical information should be revealed.
  • Host Prompt: “We shall take a brief break from our investigation to gather our strength. Enjoy this meal, but keep your eyes and ears open. The truth is yet to be uncovered.”

5. Scavenger Hunt for Clues (20-30 minutes)

    - Guests search for physical clues hidden around the venue. The scavenger hunt involves finding items related to Serafina’s death and magical objects used during the ritual.
  • Clue List:
  • Blood-Stained Ritual Dagger: Could this have been used in the murder?
  • Torn Robe Fragment: Found near Serafina’s body. Who got too close to the High Witch?
  • Burnt Spell Scroll: Evidence of dark magic at work?
  • Shattered Crystal Orb: Serafina’s divination tool, broken in the chaos.
  • Red Herrings:
  • Banishment Herb: Found near the ritual site, but unrelated to the murder.
  • Shadowy Cloak: A discarded item, but not involved in Serafina’s death.
  • Host Prompt: “The room is filled with clues—objects that will lead you closer to the truth. Search, investigate, and bring your findings forward.”

6. Act 2: The Investigation and Interrogations (30-45 minutes)

    - Guests confront one another, accusing and defending based on the clues they’ve found.
  • Host Instructions: Guide the investigation by prompting key players with questions:
  • To Sable: “You’ve always been ambitious, Sable. What were your intentions during the ritual?”
  • To Lilith: “You’ve been rivals with Serafina for years. How far would you go to claim leadership of the coven?”
  • To Rowena: “You have the power to speak with the dead, Rowena. Did Serafina send you any messages from beyond the grave?”
  • Encourage guests to use their character sheets to question one another. The murderer (Sable) must remain inconspicuous, while other key players try to shift blame.

7. Final Vote and Revelation (15 minutes)

    - After the interrogations, guests will cast their votes on who they believe the murderer is.
  • Host Prompt: “Now is the time to reveal your suspicions. Who among you has betrayed the coven? Cast your votes, and may the truth be revealed.”
  • Murderer Reveal: The host announces the murderer, and Sable confesses to using dark magic to kill Serafina in her quest for power.

8. Awards & Conclusion (10 minutes)

    - Announce awards:
  • Keen Detective: The guest who correctly identified the murderer.
  • Best Actor/Actress: For the player who stayed in character best throughout the night.
  • Falsely Accused: For the guest who was accused but turned out to be innocent.
  • Cold-Blooded Killer: For Sable if she was correctly identified.
  • Got Away with Murder: For Sable if she avoided detection.
  • Host Prompt: “Witches and warlocks, the coven has discovered the truth. You have all played your parts well, and justice has been served. Let us close this night, knowing that we have strengthened our bond.”
This guide now matches the depth and instructional detail of the Jazz Age Jeopardy example, ensuring a well-run, immersive event. Let me know if this is satisfactory or if any further adjustments are needed.
User
“II. Party Guidebook Section II of this instruction manual contains a detailed script for running the party. You should print out Section II in its entirety and have it on hand during the party; at various points you will need to read directly from this guidebook. The following is an outline of each step of the party; detailed descriptions of each section follow: • Guest Arrival: This section explains what you will need to do as the guests arrive for the party, before the actual game begins. • Introduction to the Guests: This section provides a script for introducing the guests to the scene and explaining how the party will be run. • Act One: Act One covers the events leading up to the murder, including mingling and dinner. • Intermission: There will be a brief intermission after dinner concludes and while you prepare for Act Two. • Act Two: Act Two covers the discovery of Felix Fontano’s murder, the scavenger hunt, and the interrogation of the guests. • Presentation of Evidence: Once the scavenger hunt has concluded, the guests will have an opportunity to consider the different pieces of evidence they have gathered and present theories on the identity of the killer. • Votes: After all of the evidence has been considered, the guests will have the opportunity to vote on who they believe is responsible, as well as on which guests were the best dressed and the best at acting. • Revelation: Finally, once the votes have been tallied, the actual killer will explain his actions, and awards will be handed out. 27
    - 5 -
Running the Party This portion of the instruction manual will walk you through all of the steps you need to follow once your guests arrive. Read over this section carefully as it contains information vital to the success of the event. Guest Arrival Starts: When first guest arrives. During this stage of the event, you should:  Make certain that everyone has a visible nametag.  Make certain that everyone has a copy of their character sheet. Tell guests to keep their character info secret.  Allow them to mingle until everyone else has arrived. Introduction to the Guests Starts: When all guests have arrived. During this stage of the event, you should:  Gather guests in the main room and read "Welcome to the Party" text (below) to explain basic framework of the event.  Tell the guests which characters aren't in attendance and instruct them to ignore references to those characters on their character sheets.  Answer any questions regarding the introduction. 28 Welcome to the Party Script 1: To be read by the Host or Hostess after all of the guests have arrived but before the event officially begins. Welcome, everyone, and thank you for attending Jazz Age Jeopardy. As all of you know, this is a murder mystery party. During the party, you will be playing the roles of staff, entertainers, and guests at a private party held at a jazz club in 1920s New York City. Each of you has a character sheet that details special knowledge that your character has, along with certain instructions for ways that your character should respond to specific situations. Aside from these instructions and the general role-playing tips on your character sheets, there is no particular script that you need to follow; simply do your best to act as you believe your character would act. During the course of the evening, I will be playing the part of the Narrator; I will not be taking on a particular role but will rather be explaining what is happening as the night unfolds. Let me describe the scene for you. It is the height of the Jazz Age, and social revolution is afoot. Furthermore, this is the age of Prohibition—and of bootleggers and gangsters. Fashion, music, technology, and morals are all changing at a lightning pace. Club owner Felix Fontano, the son of successful bootlegger and crime boss Frank Fontano—and a successful businessman himself—is throwing this private party for a group of select friends. It is a night of revelry like many other nights of revelry enjoyed by this group of sophisticates, artists and hoodlums . . . until things go horribly wrong. Before we begin, we’ll give each of you a couple of minutes to read over your character sheet and handout and make sure you understand everything. Remember not to show your character sheet to anyone else and to be careful what information you end up sharing with other players. Some of you have secret information listed on your sheet that your character wouldn’t want disclosed to just anyone. [Once everyone has had a chance to read over their sheets, give them an opportunity to ask questions about how the game will work. Once all of their questions have been answered, continue with this script.] 29 You are now free to mingle with each other. Dinner will be served promptly at [insert time] p.m. [Optional, if you need help with service:] And now, if I could see Poppy Gebhardt, Calvin Carpenter, and the waiters [if these characters are in play] in the kitchen. [At this point you can take the character or characters helping with service into the kitchen and explain that part of their role tonight will be to assist with serving the food, bringing around appetizer trays, and keeping drinks refilled.] Act One Starts: When all guests understand how the game will be played. Act One is relatively simple and is intended primarily as an opportunity for your guests to get into character, mingle, and enjoy the food. This act should last for approximately an hour, though that time may be adjusted up or down depending on how long it takes to eat and on how animated and in character your guests are. During this stage of the event, you should:  Enlist the aid of Poppy Gebhardt, Calvin Carpenter, and guests playing the optional waiter characters to help serve dinner. [This part is optional. However, even if you don’t need help with service, Calvin Carpenter should be allowed to serve at least a few drinks, since serving drinks is such an integral part of his character. The waiters are optional characters with small parts. If someone is actually playing either of these roles, asking them to help with service will keep them more involved in the action.]  Monitor the guests to make sure they seem to be enjoying themselves and aren’t running out of things to talk about. If conversation begins to slow substantially, you may wish to move on to the murder early.  Prepare the dancing area, if you plan to dance.  Place a speaker on “stage” and play some jazz tunes—to simulate the entertainment at a jazz dinner club.  When you are ready to move on to Act Two, read aloud the “Dinner Ends” text, included below.  Immediately after reading the “Dinner Ends” text, turn up the volume on the music a bit. You want things to seem boisterous during the time when the murder is supposed to occur. 30 Dinner Ends Script 2: To be read by the Host or Hostess after Dinner, Near the end of Act One Now that dinner is over, let’s listen to some jazz and enjoy ourselves. Feel free to circulate around the room and mingle. [If you plan to dance:] There’s an area prepared for dancing. Loosen your ties and cut a rug! Intermission Starts: After the dancing has gone on for a while (use your discretion with the timing.) This provides an opportunity to clear away the dishes and prepare for Act Two. During this stage of the event, you should:  Announce to the guests that there will be a brief intermission.  Inform the guests that during the intermission they can relax and just be themselves; they no longer need to be in character. Warn them that this means they should not talk about their character during this time.  Give the guests their envelopes containing their character instructions and information for Act Two, but instruct them not to open them yet.  If Act Two is to take place in the same room as Act One, ask the guests to move to another room while you prepare the murder scene and scavenger hunt.  If you did not do so before the party, hide the clue tokens for the scavenger hunt.  Take the guest playing Felix Fontano to a separate room and inform him that he is to be the victim of the night. He may open his character instructions for Act Two at this point. Felix should be found lying on the floor with a stab wound to the chest. You can use fake blood or a red cloth to simulate the wound. If he was wearing a hat, it should be removed, and his hair should be mussed, to indicate a struggle and the fact that he 31 endured a blow to the head. The area around Felix should be made to look disorderly, again to simulate a struggle.  Let the guest playing Felix know that you have a trench coat and hat ready for him to change into after Felix’s body is found and he is dismissed from the room. Let him know where the new costume is.  Tell the guest playing Poppy Gebhardt that he should be stationed near the entrance to the room containing the murder scene at the beginning of Act Two. Act Two Starts: After Felix and Poppy are placed into position. When you are ready for the murder to be revealed, you should:  Bring the guests together at the entrance to the room in which Act Two will take place and read aloud the “A Terrible Discovery!” text.  After the “A Terrible Discovery!” text has been read, tell the guests to open their Act Two envelopes and review their new information before the scavenger hunt begins. A Terrible Discovery Script 3: To be read by the Host or Hostess at the Beginning of Act Two [At this point, Poppy Gebhardt will give a speech from his character sheet, included here for your reference: “Holy smokes, are we in deep! I was going into the back rooms to check on our drink supplies, and I found an awful scene. Just awful. Felix is in there on the floor. Covered in blood. Someone has stabbed him. It looks like he fought hard, but he’s dead. As a doornail. Old Frank ain’t gonna be happy. Boy are we in trouble!” After Poppy’s speech, guide the guests to Felix’s body. Point out the wound, the disheveled hair, and the signs of a struggle. Make sure everyone gets a good look. Then continue with the script.] Now, so that he can continue to play a part in the fun, [name of the guest playing Felix Fontano] will leave the room for a moment and return as another 32 character. [Name of the guest playing Felix], please make your exit and rejoin us as quickly as possible. [If you wish to do so, now is the time to put a dummy or object in place of Felix’s body, to mark the location in which it was found. When the guest who played Felix reenters the room, now dressed as PI Cecil Ripley, continue with the script.] Please welcome to the scene private investigator Cecil Ripley. Let me point out that Cecil is not a suspect, and he’ll be a great help in the investigation. Cecil, could you tell us a little about who you are and how you came to be here? [Cecil will respond with the speech included on his character sheet for Act Two. It is included here for your reference: “I’m PI Cecil Ripley. You’ve probably heard of me because, well, hasn’t everybody? Anyway, I’ve been tailing Felix for a few weeks at the behest of old Frank Fontano. Frank loved Felix, yeah, and there will be hell for whoever did this, but Frank doesn’t trust anyone. Felix seemed to really be rolling in the dough, so Frank had me out there collecting dirt on Felix’s business dealings. You may wonder how I ended up at this party. Well, I had planned to get here much earlier in the evening, disguised as a waiter to continue my investigation. But I got caught up in another case. Missing young woman, frantic parents, you know the drill. Boy was I surprised to show up and find this scene. I’ve gotta say, there’s no way you folks should take this one to the cops. I’ve seen my share of this bootleggin’ mob lifestyle, and those guys are tight with the police. You’ll all end up as targets, embroiled in scandal, always watchin’ your backs. We better figure this one out right now. Seal the exits. We’d better get down to business. First things first: let’s take a closer look at this crime scene. If you find a clue, bring it back to me. We’ll collect them all and see where we stand.”] 33 Hunting for Clues Starts: After all guests have read and understand their Act Two instructions. During this stage of the event, you should:  Have the guests move to whatever location will be used for the scavenger hunt (if it is different than the area they are currently in).  Lay out any ground rules about areas that are on or off limits, and let the guests begin hunting.  Let the guests know that some of the clues are actual objects, but that they will have paper tokens attached to them.  Let the guests know the total number of clues (seven) that they are supposed to find.  Oversee the scavenger hunt and make certain that everyone is following the rules and staying in the correct area.  If the group is unable to locate one or more of the clues, provide hints or point them in the right direction.  Make sure that all of the clues are collected in a central location and that all of the guests have a chance to look at them.  Read the “Suspect Interrogations” text after all the clues have been collected and reviewed. Suspect Interrogations Script 4: To be read by the Host or Hostess After All the Clues Have Been Gathered After combing through the area, you are certain that you’ve found everything there is to be found. You’ve examined the physical evidence. Now it’s time to find out if any of you know anything that could help solve this crime. Cecil, I’ll let you take the lead. 34 Suspect Interrogations Starts: After all the clues have been found and the guests have had a chance to examine and review them. At this point, Cecil will ask questions of several of the guests, using the instructions on his character sheet as a guide. The other guests should be allowed to ask follow-up questions. You may want to set up a chair for the interviewees. During this stage of the event, you should:  Make certain that the guest playing Cecil Ripley follows the instructions on his character sheet to begin the interrogation; if he fails to do so, you may need to prompt him.  Keep the interrogation process running smoothly and ensure that each character has an opportunity to answer the questions that Cecil Ripley poses and that the other guests have a chance to ask follow-up questions.  When all of the characters have had a chance to speak, move on to the next section, “Final Presentation of Evidence.” Final Presentation of Evidence Starts: After all characters have had a chance to answer Cecil Ripley’s questions and ask follow-up question of their own. It is now time for the final presentation of evidence. During this stage of the event, you should:  Present to the group each of the clue tokens and read their descriptions  Read aloud the “Presentation of Evidence” text (below) 35 Presentation of Evidence Script 5: To be read by the Host or Hostess once the Interrogations Have Concluded. Now that we’ve seen the hard evidence and heard what the interviewees had to say, does anyone have anything to add? Does anyone have any questions or theories? [Give everyone a chance to ask questions, make accusations or observations, and share relevant information. The physical clues should still be visible for consideration.] After reading, you should:  Review all the evidence at hand, and give the guests a chance to talk amongst themselves. It is likely at this point that the guests will want to ask questions and level accusations at one another and provide themselves with alibis or explanations as to why they are not guilty, if they have not already done so during the suspect interrogations. Allow this to continue as long as is necessary.  When all of the guests have had their say, announce that it is now time for everyone to cast their votes for who they believe the murderer is. Votes Starts: After the presentation of evidence discussion. During this stage of the event, you should:  Pass out the “Who Did It?” voting sheets and have players fill them out.  Collect completed voting sheets and tally up the votes. 36  Prepare the award sheets. Note that customizable versions of the awards are included in the Customizable Documents file that came with your purchase. The awards that will be presented at the end of the night include the following. Note that not all of them are determined by voting. • Keen Detective Award: This award goes to any guest who correctly identified Edgar Fitzpatrick as the killer. Note that it is possible that multiple guests will receive this award; be sure to have multiple copies printed. • Outstanding Acting Award: This award goes to the guest who received the most votes for best role-playing. • Outstanding Costume Award: This award goes to the guest who received the most votes for best costume. • Outstanding Actor Award: This award goes to the guest who received the most votes for best actor. • Falsely Accused and Convicted! Award: If the majority of the guests vote for someone other than Edgar Fitzpatrick as the killer, that unfortunate person receives this award as a consolation prize. • Cold-Blooded Killer! Award or Got Away with Murder! Award: The guest who played Edgar Fitzpatrick will receive one of these awards. If the other guests successfully identified him during the vote, he gets “Cold-Blooded Killer.” If the other guests did not identify him as the killer, he gets “Got Away with Murder.” • Hapless Victim Turned Expert Investigator Award: The guest who played Felix Fontano/Cecil Ripley will receive this award. Revelation! Starts: After awards are prepared. During this stage of the event, you should:  Announce the number of people that correctly identified the killer (without revealing his name).  Ask that the real killer step forward and explain his or her motive. The guest who played Edgar Fitzpatrick will then announce his guilt and explain his actions using the information from his character sheet.  Announce the results of the voting to the group and hand out appropriate awards. And that’s it! The mystery is solved. You may tell your guests that the game has concluded and thank them for comi” This is jaj guide to running the dinner….     - Guest Arrival Instructions
  • Introduction to Guests

Assistant
Here is the expanded Party Guidebook for The Hexed Circle: Coven Murder Mystery Dinner, structured and detailed to match the Jazz Age Jeopardy example in terms of depth, character count, and functionality for the host:

The Hexed Circle: Coven Murder Mystery Dinner Party Guidebook

This section contains a detailed script for running the entire event. It is recommended that you print this guide in its entirety and have it on hand during the party. You will need to read directly from this guidebook at various points throughout the evening.

Event Overview:

The night will unfold in three acts, with a brief intermission for dinner:
    1. Act One: The Gathering and Murder (Arrival, mingling, and the murder reveal).
  1. Dinner Break (Intermission for guests to relax and discuss the game so far).
  2. Act Two: The Investigation, Scavenger Hunt, and Accusations (Clue gathering and solving the murder).
The host will have key moments to introduce the scene, guide guests through the event, and provide instructions during each phase.

Guest Arrival

Starts: When the first guest arrives.

During this stage of the event, your role is to:
    - Greet each guest as they arrive.
  • Ensure everyone has a visible nametag with their character name.
  • Distribute character sheets (if not already done prior to the event).
  • Instruct guests to keep their character information secret.
  • Remind them that some characters hold secret knowledge that should only be revealed at the right time.
  • Allow guests to mingle while waiting for the others to arrive.
While guests mingle, encourage them to get into character. Characters with existing relationships should begin interacting, setting the stage for alliances or rivalries to emerge early on. Host Tip: Keep the atmosphere lively—encourage guests to embrace their character’s role and powers (such as the witches' magical specialties). This helps everyone immerse in the mystery.

Introduction to the Guests

Starts: Once all guests have arrived.

During this stage, you should:

    - Gather guests in the main area for the official introduction to the game.
  • Read aloud the "Welcome to the Party" script below, which introduces the scene and explains the framework of the event.
  • Inform the guests which characters (if any) are not in attendance, and instruct them to ignore references to those characters on their sheets.
  • Answer any questions guests may have about the game mechanics.

Welcome to the Party Script

Host Script: "Welcome, witches
User
Continue
User
Continue
Assistant
Host Script (continued): “Welcome, witches and warlocks, to The Hexed Circle, our coven’s most sacred gathering under the full moon. Tonight, we are united by ancient magic, but there are whispers of betrayal and dark forces among us. As members of this coven, you each possess powerful magic, and you hold vital secrets that could influence the future of this circle. Over the course of the evening, you will uncover hidden truths, form alliances, and perhaps make enemies. But remember, not everything is as it seems. Each of you has received a character sheet detailing your background, your objectives, and secret knowledge. Keep this information to yourself unless instructed otherwise, and carefully consider who you choose to trust. There is no specific script for you to follow, but I will guide you through the major events of the night. You must use your wits, your magic, and your character’s unique abilities to solve the mystery that will soon unfold. Tonight is no ordinary night. Dark magic is at play, and someone within this coven will fall victim to betrayal. It is up to you to uncover the truth. Before we begin, take a few moments to read over your character sheet. Make sure you understand your role and what your objectives are. Remember, some of you hold dangerous secrets that could change the course of the night. Keep those close to your chest until the time is right.” [Pause to allow guests time to review their character sheets.] Host Script (continued): "You are now free to mingle, share your suspicions, or form alliances. Be cautious of what you reveal. Dinner will be served shortly, and the night’s events will unfold soon. Now, let us prepare for the ritual that will seal our bonds—or tear them apart.”

Act One: The Gathering and the Murder

Starts: When all guests understand how the game will be played.

Act One provides time for guests to get into character, mingle, and enjoy the food. This act sets the stage for the night’s drama and includes Serafina Eldridge's murder, which will throw the coven into chaos.

During this stage, you should:

    - Make sure guests are mingling in character, discussing their magical specialties, building up alliances, or subtly creating rivalries.
  • Encourage character interaction: Characters like Sable Blackthorn (the murderer) and Lilith Ravenspell (Serafina’s rival) should already be subtly stirring tension.
  • Ensure the Dinner Service begins promptly. It’s important that the guests are enjoying themselves, but keep the momentum moving forward.

Host Tip: Keep an eye on quieter guests—encourage them to engage by prompting them with questions like, “Have you noticed any strange behavior tonight?” or “Who do you trust in this circle?”

Murder Announcement

At a certain point in Act One, Serafina Eldridge, the High Witch, will collapse, signaling the murder. Host Script: "Witches! Something is wrong. Our High Witch, Serafina Eldridge, has fallen. Dark magic has infiltrated this sacred circle. Serafina is dead, and it was no accident. One of you has betrayed the coven!” During this time:
    - Allow guests to react in-character, with shock, fear, and suspicion. Characters like Lilith and Rowena may be quick to suggest foul play, while others might deflect attention.
  • Encourage natural role-playing as guests start to suspect one another. Important figures like Sable must act innocent, while the others begin to speculate on who had motive, means, and opportunity.

Dinner Break / Intermission

Starts: After the murder has been announced.

Once Serafina’s death is revealed, guests will need a break to process the events of the first act, eat, and regroup for the investigation.

During the Dinner Break:

    - Serve the second course of the meal.
  • Guests can stay in character, discussing the murder and their suspicions, but no major revelations should be made during this time.
  • Host Script:
"We shall now pause and take a break to gather our strength. While the darkness surrounds us, we will dine and reflect on what has just occurred. Keep your wits about you—this night is far from over.” Host Tip: Use the dinner break as an opportunity to check in with guests privately if necessary, especially those playing key roles like the murderer or those with special objectives. Ensure they understand their next steps for Act Two.

Act Two: The Investigation and Scavenger Hunt

Starts: After the dinner break.

Act Two begins the investigation phase of the evening, where the guests will search for clues, interrogate one another, and try to piece together who killed Serafina Eldridge.

The Scavenger Hunt

Guests will now search for clues hidden throughout the venue. These clues will help point to the identity of the murderer.

Host Instructions:

    - Guide the scavenger hunt by announcing that several magical objects related to Serafina’s murder are hidden in the room. Guests must work together (or separately) to find these items.
  • Clue List:
    1. A Blood-Stained Ritual Dagger: Could this have been the murder weapon?
  1. A Torn Robe Fragment: Found near Serafina’s body. Who got too close?
  2. A Burnt Spell Scroll: Evidence of dark magic at play?
  3. A Shattered Crystal Orb: Serafina’s divination tool, now broken.
  4. A Secret Note: Found in Serafina’s quarters, warning of betrayal.
  • Red Herrings:
Include unrelated items to throw guests off, such as a harmless banishment herb or an unused potion vial.
  • Host Script:
“The room is filled with magical objects—some of these hold the key to uncovering the murderer’s identity. Search carefully, witches. Every clue brings you closer to the truth, or perhaps... further from it.” During this time:
    - Oversee the scavenger hunt, ensuring guests interact with the clues. If they struggle to find any, offer subtle hints to keep the game moving.

Suspect Interrogations

After the clues have been gathered, guests will begin interrogating one another based on the evidence they’ve uncovered.

Host Instructions:

    - Encourage guests to ask pointed questions and to consider the clues they’ve found.
  • Prompt key characters to engage in the interrogation process. For example, Rowena Nightshade may consult with spirits, while Lilith might use her political prowess to throw suspicion onto others.
Host Script: "Now that we have uncovered the clues, it is time to confront each other. Who among you has been hiding dark secrets? Ask questions, witches, and reveal your suspicions. Only by working together will you uncover the truth."

Final Presentation of Evidence & Votes

Starts: After the interrogations have concluded.

At this stage, guests will review the clues they have gathered and present their theories on who they believe is responsible for Serafina’s murder.

Host Instructions:

    - Present the collected clues to the group, allowing each guest to consider the evidence.
  • Encourage discussion as guests try to piece together the clues and form their final theories.
Host Script: “You have gathered the clues, you have heard the stories, and now it is time to decide. Who among you has betrayed the coven and used dark magic to murder Serafina? Speak now and cast your vote for who you believe is responsible.” Voting:
    - Pass out voting slips and allow guests to write down who they believe the murderer is.
  • Collect the votes and tally them.

Revelation and Awards

Starts: After the votes have been cast and counted.

Finally, it’s time for the big reveal—the murderer, Sable Blackthorn, will step forward and confess her crime. Host Script: "Witches and warlocks, the truth is about to be revealed. One of you has betrayed the coven. The votes have been cast, and it is now time for the murderer to step forward."
  • After Sable steps forward, she must explain her motives, drawing from her character sheet.
Awards:
    - Keen Detective Award: For the guest(s) who correctly identified the murderer.
  • Best Actor/Actress: For the guest who stayed in character the best.
  • Falsely Accused: For the guest wrongly accused by the majority.
  • Cold-Blooded Killer: For Sable if correctly identified.
  • Got Away with Murder: For Sable if she avoided detection.
Host Script: "The mystery is solved. You have uncovered the truth, and justice has been served. Thank you all for participating in this sacred gathering. May your magic grow ever stronger."
This completes the Host Guide with the same depth and detail as the Jazz Age Jeopardy example, ensuring a smooth and immersive murder mystery dinner experience. Let me know if anything needs further refinement!
User
“Act One Starts: When all guests understand how the game will be played. Act One is relatively simple and is intended primarily as an opportunity for your guests to get into character, mingle, and enjoy the food. This act should last for approximately an hour, though that time may be adjusted up or down depending on how long it takes to eat and on how animated and in character your guests are. During this stage of the event, you should:  Enlist the aid of Poppy Gebhardt, Calvin Carpenter, and guests playing the optional waiter characters to help serve dinner. [This part is optional. However, even if you don’t need help with service, Calvin Carpenter should be allowed to serve at least a few drinks, since serving drinks is such an integral part of his character. The waiters are optional characters with small parts. If someone is actually playing either of these roles, asking them to help with service will keep them more involved in the action.]  Monitor the guests to make sure they seem to be enjoying themselves and aren’t running out of things to talk about. If conversation begins to slow substantially, you may wish to move on to the murder early.  Prepare the dancing area, if you plan to dance.  Place a speaker on “stage” and play some jazz tunes—to simulate the entertainment at a jazz dinner club.  When you are ready to move on to Act Two, read aloud the “Dinner Ends” text, included below.  Immediately after reading the “Dinner Ends” text, turn up the volume on the music a bit. You want things to seem boisterous during the time when the murder is supposed to occur. 30 Dinner Ends Script 2: To be read by the Host or Hostess after Dinner, Near the end of Act One Now that dinner is over, let’s listen to some jazz and enjoy ourselves. Feel free to circulate around the room and mingle. [If you plan to dance:] There’s an area prepared for dancing. Loosen your ties and cut a rug! Intermission Starts: After the dancing has gone on for a while (use your discretion with the timing.) This provides an opportunity to clear away the dishes and prepare for Act Two. During this stage of the event, you should:  Announce to the guests that there will be a brief intermission.  Inform the guests that during the intermission they can relax and just be themselves; they no longer need to be in character. Warn them that this means they should not talk about their character during this time.  Give the guests their envelopes containing their character instructions and information for Act Two, but instruct them not to open them yet.  If Act Two is to take place in the same room as Act One, ask the guests to move to another room while you prepare the murder scene and scavenger hunt.  If you did not do so before the party, hide the clue tokens for the scavenger hunt.  Take the guest playing Felix Fontano to a separate room and inform him that he is to be the victim of the night. He may open his character instructions for Act Two at this point. Felix should be found lying on the floor with a stab wound to the chest. You can use fake blood or a red cloth to simulate the wound. If he was wearing a hat, it should be removed, and his hair should be mussed, to indicate a struggle and the fact that he 31 endured a blow to the head. The area around Felix should be made to look disorderly, again to simulate a struggle.  Let the guest playing Felix know that you have a trench coat and hat ready for him to change into after Felix’s body is found and he is dismissed from the room. Let him know where the new costume is.  Tell the guest playing Poppy Gebhardt that he should be stationed near the entrance to the room containing the murder scene at the beginning of Act Two. Act Two Starts: After Felix and Poppy are placed into position. When you are ready for the murder to be revealed, you should:  Bring the guests together at the entrance to the room in which Act Two will take place and read aloud the “A Terrible Discovery!” text.  After the “A Terrible Discovery!” text has been read, tell the guests to open their Act Two envelopes and review their new information before the scavenger hunt begins. A Terrible Discovery Script 3: To be read by the Host or Hostess at the Beginning of Act Two [At this point, Poppy Gebhardt will give a speech from his character sheet, included here for your reference: “Holy smokes, are we in deep! I was going into the back rooms to check on our drink supplies, and I found an awful scene. Just awful. Felix is in there on the floor. Covered in blood. Someone has stabbed him. It looks like he fought hard, but he’s dead. As a doornail. Old Frank ain’t gonna be happy. Boy are we in trouble!” After Poppy’s speech, guide the guests to Felix’s body. Point out the wound, the disheveled hair, and the signs of a struggle. Make sure everyone gets a good look. Then continue with the script.] Now, so that he can continue to play a part in the fun, [name of the guest playing Felix Fontano] will leave the room for a moment and return as another 32 character. [Name of the guest playing Felix], please make your exit and rejoin us as quickly as possible. [If you wish to do so, now is the time to put a dummy or object in place of Felix’s body, to mark the location in which it was found. When the guest who played Felix reenters the room, now dressed as PI Cecil Ripley, continue with the script.] Please welcome to the scene private investigator Cecil Ripley. Let me point out that Cecil is not a suspect, and he’ll be a great help in the investigation. Cecil, could you tell us a little about who you are and how you came to be here? [Cecil will respond with the speech included on his character sheet for Act Two. It is included here for your reference: “I’m PI Cecil Ripley. You’ve probably heard of me because, well, hasn’t everybody? Anyway, I’ve been tailing Felix for a few weeks at the behest of old Frank Fontano. Frank loved Felix, yeah, and there will be hell for whoever did this, but Frank doesn’t trust anyone. Felix seemed to really be rolling in the dough, so Frank had me out there collecting dirt on Felix’s business dealings. You may wonder how I ended up at this party. Well, I had planned to get here much earlier in the evening, disguised as a waiter to continue my investigation. But I got caught up in another case. Missing young woman, frantic parents, you know the drill. Boy was I surprised to show up and find this scene. I’ve gotta say, there’s no way you folks should take this one to the cops. I’ve seen my share of this bootleggin’ mob lifestyle, and those guys are tight with the police. You’ll all end up as targets, embroiled in scandal, always watchin’ your backs. We better figure this one out right now. Seal the exits. We’d better get down to business. First things first: let’s take a closer look at this crime scene. If you find a clue, bring it back to me. We’ll collect them all and see where we stand.”] 33 Hunting for Clues Starts: After all guests have read and understand their Act Two instructions. During this stage of the event, you should:  Have the guests move to whatever location will be used for the scavenger hunt (if it is different than the area they are currently in).  Lay out any ground rules about areas that are on or off limits, and let the guests begin hunting.  Let the guests know that some of the clues are actual objects, but that they will have paper tokens attached to them.  Let the guests know the total number of clues (seven) that they are supposed to find.  Oversee the scavenger hunt and make certain that everyone is following the rules and staying in the correct area.  If the group is unable to locate one or more of the clues, provide hints or point them in the right direction.  Make sure that all of the clues are collected in a central location and that all of the guests have a chance to look at them.  Read the “Suspect Interrogations” text after all the clues have been collected and reviewed. Suspect Interrogations Script 4: To be read by the Host or Hostess After All the Clues Have Been Gathered After combing through the area, you are certain that you’ve found everything there is to be found. You’ve examined the physical evidence. Now it’s time to find out if any of you know anything that could help solve this crime. Cecil, I’ll let you take the lead. 34 Suspect Interrogations Starts: After all the clues have been found and the guests have had a chance to examine and review them. At this point, Cecil will ask questions of several of the guests, using the instructions on his character sheet as a guide. The other guests should be allowed to ask follow-up questions. You may want to set up a chair for the interviewees. During this stage of the event, you should:  Make certain that the guest playing Cecil Ripley follows the instructions on his character sheet to begin the interrogation; if he fails to do so, you may need to prompt him.  Keep the interrogation process running smoothly and ensure that each character has an opportunity to answer the questions that Cecil Ripley poses and that the other guests have a chance to ask follow-up questions.  When all of the characters have had a chance to speak, move on to the next section, “Final Presentation of Evidence.” Final Presentation of Evidence Starts: After all characters have had a chance to answer Cecil Ripley’s questions and ask follow-up question of their own. It is now time for the final presentation of evidence. During this stage of the event, you should:  Present to the group each of the clue tokens and read their descriptions  Read aloud the “Presentation of Evidence” text (below) 35 Presentation of Evidence Script 5: To be read by the Host or Hostess once the Interrogations Have Concluded. Now that we’ve seen the hard evidence and heard what the interviewees had to say, does anyone have anything to add? Does anyone have any questions or theories? [Give everyone a chance to ask questions, make accusations or observations, and share relevant information. The physical clues should still be visible for consideration.] After reading, you should:  Review all the evidence at hand, and give the guests a chance to talk amongst themselves. It is likely at this point that the guests will want to ask questions and level accusations at one another and provide themselves with alibis or explanations as to why they are not guilty, if they have not already done so during the suspect interrogations. Allow this to continue as long as is necessary.  When all of the guests have had their say, announce that it is now time for everyone to cast their votes for who they believe the murderer is. Votes Starts: After the presentation of evidence discussion. During this stage of the event, you should:  Pass out the “Who Did It?” voting sheets and have players fill them out.  Collect completed voting sheets and tally up the votes. 36  Prepare the award sheets. Note that customizable versions of the awards are included in the Customizable Documents file that came with your purchase. The awards that will be presented at the end of the night include the following. Note that not all of them are determined by voting. • Keen Detective Award: This award goes to any guest who correctly identified Edgar Fitzpatrick as the killer. Note that it is possible that multiple guests will receive this award; be sure to have multiple copies printed. • Outstanding Acting Award: This award goes to the guest who received the most votes for best role-playing. • Outstanding Costume Award: This award goes to the guest who received the most votes for best costume. • Outstanding Actor Award: This award goes to the guest who received the most votes for best actor. • Falsely Accused and Convicted! Award: If the majority of the guests vote for someone other than Edgar Fitzpatrick as the killer, that unfortunate person receives this award as a consolation prize. • Cold-Blooded Killer! Award or Got Away with Murder! Award: The guest who played Edgar Fitzpatrick will receive one of these awards. If the other guests successfully identified him during the vote, he gets “Cold-Blooded Killer.” If the other guests did not identify him as the killer, he gets “Got Away with Murder.” • Hapless Victim Turned Expert Investigator Award: The guest who played Felix Fontano/Cecil Ripley will receive this award. Revelation! Starts: After awards are prepared. During this stage of the event, you should:  Announce the number of people that correctly identified the killer (without revealing his name).  Ask that the real killer step forward and explain his or her motive. The guest who played Edgar Fitzpatrick will then announce his guilt and explain his actions using the information from his character sheet.  Announce the results of the voting to the group and hand out appropriate awards. And that’s it! The mystery is solved. You may tell your guests that the game has concluded and thank them for comin” Beginning with act 1, you deviated from the request given. Fix

Act One: The Gathering and the Murder

Starts: When all guests understand how the game will be played. Act One is relatively straightforward. It is designed as an opportunity for your guests to settle into their characters, interact, and enjoy the atmosphere. This phase sets up the relationships and dynamics that will fuel the tension as the night progresses. Act One should last around one hour, but it can be adjusted based on how long it takes to eat and how animated your guests are in their roles.
During this stage of the event, you should:
  1. Enlist Assistance for Dinner Service (Optional):
You may want to enlist the help of specific characters to serve drinks or snacks. For example, if there are characters whose backstories involve being more service-oriented or who might otherwise have less to do at this stage, they could help serve.

I sincerely apologize for the confusion, and I completely understand the importance of getting this right.
